Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 12:27PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: Beautiful.  When I was first diagnosed and had surgery, my eldest son who was twenty was very quiet about it.  Then a few weeks later he gave me a CD with a song that he wrote for me.  He writes songs all of the time, but this was extra special.  In the background, he took from a DVD that we had the words of me calling him when he was a baby. He dispersed this through these beautiful lyrics that he wrote about our relationship.  Talk about tearjerker.  The disease sure sucks, but the love from our boys is incredible, huh?!! God bless----
Posts.Title: My Son made me cry yesterday kim40 Rhonda1966

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2009 05:26PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: What else can I say that everyone else hasn't? My love, prayers and good wishes to your sweet daughter and your family.  We are here to hug you when you need it.
Posts.Title: HELP! 10 year old with bc cjsocal Mary-Lou

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 05:42AM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: Yes, very normal.  Had two separate mastectomies. One for DCIS and then another prophylactic a year later.  Just when I thought my drains were ready to be pulled, the numbers went up again.  So annoying!  My doctor said that sometimes there is a pocket in there that lets loose.  Better to have the drains in even though they are a nuisance to ensure that most fluid is out.  There is nowhere for this fluid to go except through your system when they are out.  You want to make sure the numbers are low enough for you body to handle it.  I would check out the fluid around the incision though.  That may be unrelated to the fluid coming out of the drain.  Make sure your incision isn't infected.  Good luck and hugs.
Posts.Title: One week post-mx increased drainage? Faith316 Faith316

Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2009 05:47PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: How can anyone tell you what your treatment options will be even before they biopsied the calcifications?  Hopefully, things will turn out benign.  In the small chance that it isnt, it doesn't necessarily mean that you need radiation or chemo!  Do not do anything until you have the results of your biopsy.  You need to relax when you get the results and make decisions from there.  Hopefully, there won't be any decisions to be made.  I am sorry, I don't know anything about health insurance but please don't let your doctors scare you.  What the doctor said would scare me too. Just have the biopsy and proceed from there.  That is the only thing that you need done right now.  Do not make any decisions until you have the results.  Hugs and prayers your way.
Posts.Title: Found Small Lump -Diagnostic Mamo and Ultrasound are Clear jeannemh lamomimax1
Just found out, please help me LRM216 gmw

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 04:42AM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: I'm assuming that you have DCIS which is associated with calcifications.  If so, it is ok to take some time to weigh your decisions.  I found out that I had DCIS in July and I wasn't operated on until the end of September.  That was because I was weighing between a lumpectomy and mastectomy.  I chose the mastectomy because I had it in more than one area.  Then there was time to hook up an available time for both my plastic surgeon and breast surgeon to be there together.  I don't blame you for considering a double mastectomy.  I am thinking of going back in to have my other breast removed in June because I can't deal with the stress of mammographies, MRI, sonograms etc.  Everyone is different.  It is not spreading.  Take a deep breath, make sure that you make the decision that is right for you and try (I know it is really difficult) to relax.
Posts.Title: waiting for surgery rebilla rebilla

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2009 04:33AM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: Yes, I had my exchange before finishing my fills.  I was a bit nervous at the outcome as my original surgery from mastectomy was in September and I had my exchange in February.  We didn't even begin filling until the beginning of December because I had an infection.  My doc quickly filled me (3 times) and then waited only two weeks to do the exchange. (and muscle repair!)  I wound up with a smalll C cup, which is just fine.  My plastic surgeon told me I can now go bigger if I want to.  I just had a prophylactic July 13 and when they go to exchange on that side, he can revise the original.  But things healed just fine and I am comfortable with leaving it alone.  Talk to your doctor about using Alloderm.  That strengthens the area where the implant goes on.  My doctor said he should have used it on me when I had the expander and this time around he did.  But when he exchanged to implant, he used it then to prevent further complications.
Posts.Title: incision infections MillieD swimangel72

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2009 10:13AM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: Yes, I have been down this road too.  In my initial mastectomy back last September, I had nipple sparing that got necrotic and infected.  I had debridement, packing and antibiotics for months.  Once we got that under control, one of my incisions opened up after some fills too and my muscle became exposed.  Thank goodness, my implant didn't become infected,but we had to do the exchange surgery quicker than I wanted to.  It seems like this isn't too uncommon, though when you are going through it, you feel very alone.  Reassurance here that it will turn out okay.  There are so many obstacles on this journey but somehow we survive.  Good luck and hang in there.
Posts.Title: incision infections MillieD swimangel72

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2009 07:14PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: Hi Mary.  I know the "waiting game" is the HARDEST part of the whole journey.  When I went for my biopsy it was a Tuesday, no results by Friday and then I had to call on Monday.  Mine turned out to be DCIS.  I thought I was going to die at that moment.  I was 44 years old.  My mom had died at 49 from breast cancer but that was 22 years ago.  Treatment and early diagnosis has come a long way since then.  You are absolutely right.  Even the most supportive of husbands and families sometimes don't understand the emotions that you are going through.  You have found the right place for answers and support.  Try to hang in there.  Most biopsies turn out to be benign.  Live for the moment (easier said than done) and try to keep your mind occupied.  My prayers and thoughts are with you.
Posts.Title: Going out of my mind TexasRose momo3esb

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2009 11:26PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: 51.  Why didn't your doctor put in your implants through a tiny needle in the belly button the way girls on t.v. have it done when they have their breasts enhanced?
Posts.Title: 100 things never to say to a woman who has had a mastectomy: iwannabefree jillyG

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2009 04:08PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: I had a unilateral for scattered DCIS in Sept 2008.  After having monitoring on my other healthy breast for almost a year, I decided mentally I could not do this for the rest of my life.  I chose to have a prophylactic in July 2009.  I also have a strong family history of breast cancer, saw my mom and aunt suffer and die from the disease even though my genetic test came back negative. It is an individual choice.  Some people can handle the close surveillance and move on with their life.  Some people like me get so overwhelmed and rather be done with it.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic bilateral mx simmonba CAROLMARIE427

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2009 02:14PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: Hi Sparky.  Hugs and prayers to you and your wife during this difficult time.  I think that your wife is still in denial.  That is the first step that any woman with breast cancer goes through.   I don't think that there are statistics out there for women who don't do surgery.  Right now, from a woman's perspective, she can't think about having a mastectomy or lumpectomy or whatever treatment may follow.  Just take one day at a time, and let her rant and ask you crazy questions.  Hopefully, the biopsy will come back benign. I do think that talking about mastectomy when you don't even have a diagnosis yet would set any woman back.  Unfortunately, I don't live in your area to suggest a surgeon, but I bet you can google top doctors or look in America's Top Doctors book to find out.  I agree with someone else that posted to find a comprehensive breast care center where the surgeon, oncologist, radiologist etc.  all work together.  Try not to get overwhelmed until you know for sure what you are dealing with.
Posts.Title: Where to start? sparkyhammerjigsaw CinD

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2009 10:31PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: I had a prophylactic 10 months after my original mastectomy and my insurance company (GHI) paid for that and the reconstruction in full.  I was BRCA negative but I fit the criteria for a strong family history and a personal history of breast cancer.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic (Mastectomy #2) and Insurance NMB NMB

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2009 06:20PM CAROLMARIE427 wrote: Surgery and the unknown is always scary,  The worst part of both of my operations for mastectomy and implant exchange was anticipating that god knew what was going to happen, which of course never did.  Your mind can play so many mean tricks on you.  I am deathly afraid of anesthesia because I never had it before.  But it was fine-they give you something that makes you a bit loopy and then you are woken up and can't believe it is over.  The pain level is well controlled by drugs.  Like someone else said, take one step at a time.  Otherwise, you will really get yourself crazy.  Ask your doctor for some relaxers if you cannot control your fear.
